isis.stitle: TSI 93-16-09 - Repair Water Leaks on Second Generation Bentz Sleeper Boxes

subjectgroup.subject: Repair Water Leaks on Second Generation Bentz Sleeper Boxes

geninfo.para: Navistar began building 9200, 9300 and 9400 models equipped with the "2nd Generation Bentz" sleeper boxes starting on 01/04/93. This new family of sleeper boxes includes 48 inch flat roof (codes 16SBE, 16SBG or 16SBH), 60 inch flat roof (codes 16SBJ, 16SBK or 16SBL), and 60 inch Cantilever (code 16SBM).

Complaints of water leaking into the sleeper box, received on the initial production of these boxes, has prompted Navistar to initiate a program of inspection, repair and water testing intended to minimize customer dissatisfaction.
When a sleeper box water leak complaint is received, the following items and areas need to be inspected and repaired as needed: Repair instructions are furnished under SERVICE PROCEDURES.

item.para: Presence of polyurethane foam in the six corners of the bottom of the sleeper box. Some boxes may have gray sealer in these areas which is acceptable and does not require foam.
Visible gaps or voids in the sealer between the box skin and the tool box door and between the box skin and the exit door frames.
Visible gaps or voids in the sealer at the perimeter of the top of the box both above and below the drip rail and at the top and bottom of the back panel.
Visible gaps or voids in the sealer at the perimeter of the top of the box both above and below the drip rail and at the top and bottom of the back panel.
Presence of the 8 or 10 plastic plugs (under the rubber mat) in the floor of the box.
Proper sealing of the tool box and exit doors.
Sealer between the plastic 7-way electrical socket and the rear of the sleeper box.
Sealer between the 5th wheel lights and the rear of the sleeper box.
Clear sealer to be used is a non-silicone latex sealer.
GEOCEL "PRO-FLEX" or "WATER SHIELD". Part Number 2643819R1 is available through PDC. It is also available at Ace or True Value Hardware Stores.
12 oz. container foam fill insulation. Fomo Products "Handi Foam" or equivalent polyurethane foam which can be obtained from local hardware/lumber yards, or call 1-216-753-4585.
3/16 inch diameter aluminum blind head rivet, Part Number 403061-C1, Quantity 6.
Upholstery tack dry type glue or contact cement.

svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE

step1.para: Inspect for the presence of polyurethane foam in all six corners of the underbody of the sleeper box. Some boxes may have gray sealer in these areas which is acceptable and does not require foam. If the foam is not present repair as follows:
Inspect for visible gaps or voids in the sealer between the box skin and the frame of both the tool box and exit door ( Figure 1).

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. SEAL FRONT RADIUS OF UNDERBODY WITH CLEAR SEALER-SKIN TO FLOOR AT RADIUS AND 3 HOLES, BOTH SIDES.

FOAM UNDERBODY - USE "HANDI FOAM" (POLYURETHANE) OR EQUIVALENT. FOAM 6 INDIVIDUAL CORNER IN SIDE POSTS - 3 EACH SIDE FOAM BOTH FRONT ROUNDED CORNERS. INSERT FOAM NOZZLE IN 1/2 INCH HOLE AT UNDERBODY - BOTH SIDES OF BOX (SEE NOTE BELOW)
FOAM CUTOUTS BELOW EACH DOOR - BOTH SIDES
KNIFE CUT EXCESS FOAM EXTENDING BELOW BOTTOM OF BOX.

note.para: When completed, foam may extend from inboard of rear corner post along each side, around front corner and inboard of front center corner post.

step1.para: Inspect for visible gaps or voids in the sealer at the top of the box above and below drip rail and at the top and bottom of the back pane ( Figure 2).

figure.caption: Figure 2. Applying Sealer To Top Of Box And Back Panel

calloutgroup.callout1: *1. SEAL OUTSIDE PERIMETER OF TOP OF BOX ABOVE AND BELOW DRIP RAIL WITH CLEAR SEALER.
*2. SEAL GAPS AT BACK PANEL JOINTS - TOP AND BOTTOM OF BOX WITH CLEAR SEALER.
*3. SEAL AROUND PERIMETER OF BOTH DOOR FRAMES WITH CLEAR SEALER.
4. SMOOTH/REMOVE EXCESS SEALER FOR COSMETIC APPEARANCE.
*Preferred method is to push the sealer gun along the joint to be sealed vs. pulling the gun along the joint.

step1.para: Inspect for the proper installation of the 8 or 10 plastic filler plugs under the floor mat in the box. Missing plugs must be replaced. If you do not have the proper size plugs in inventory, duct tape can be used to cover the hole from the inside.

step2.para: (2) Plugs - 1 at each front corner (may not be present on some boxes)

step1.para: Inspect for the proper sealing of both the tool box and exit rubber door seals for no visible light between door and seal. Adjust the door (at the hinge), seal or bend the seal fence to insure proper contact between the seal and the perimeter of the door. The seal should not contact the door trim panel - particularly along the top edge of the door. If seal contacts the trim, water may leak inside between the door and the trim panel. To repair:

step2.para: With the door closed, mark face of trim panel along bottom edge of seal with a pencil to determine the amount of material to be removed to shorten the trim board.
Remove the trim panel and measure area under the seal - from pencil mark to top of trim panel.
Pull trim loose from back side of door trim and fold under.
Mark area to be removed from panel backing board and cut area being careful not to damage face trim
Spray Tack Dry Upholstery Glue or Contact Cement to back side of panel and restretch trim material and stick edges to back side of panel.
Re-install door trim panel and check for interference to seal.

svcproc.para: The seal may need to be pulled away from the fence to insure contact with the door. The seal flange may also need to be straightened to eliminate the step in the flange.
If the door seal is kinked in the corners the seal should be removed from the fence and re-installed in a different position so the same part of the seal is not in the corner.
Clear sealer should be applied if there is a visible gap on the door frame seal fence at the butt joint. Remove the seal and apply sealer on the inside of the seal flange at the butt joint.
The final fit and adjustment must insure that no light enters the sleeper box through the door to seal joint due to contact between the seal and the interior trim panel on the exit door.

step1.para: The plastic 7-way socket should be removed and clear sealer applied on all sleeper boxes on trucks built before June 1, 1993. Remove the seal around the large diameter of the connector body and re-install with the original gasket. Also, apply sealer on the backside of the connector where the ends of the cover springs protrude through the face of the connector. Apply sealer to the threads of the bolts when re-installing.
Both 5th wheel lights should be removed and clear sealer applied between the light housing and the back panel of the sleeper box on all trucks built before February 22, 1993.
Drill out the three mounting rivets and apply a wide bead of clear sealer to the backside of the light where the mounting flange and the housing meet.

The bead of sealer should be within the inside diameter of the paper mounting gasket and should result in a solid bead between the light housing and the back panel on the inside of the sleeper box. Re-install the light using 3/16 inch blind head rivets.
Sealer should also be installed between light lens and the light housing.

svcproc.title: WATER TESTING
svcproc.para: High pressure washing is recommended in order to assure that all the potential sources of water leaks have been corrected. After steps 1 thru 7 have been completed and any sealer which had been added has been allowed to cure (see instructions on sealer for cure time), the sleeper box must be tested for water leaks by high pressure washing.

The interior of the sleeper box and tool box should then be thoroughly inspected for the presence of water. If water is found, the source of the leak must be identified and corrected. Additional high pressure washing should be performed to verify that the source of the leak has been corrected.
